Award.AwardTitle: Phase One data rescue of the Austin Post air photo collection and new repeat aerial photography of Alaskan valley glaciers
Award.AbstractNarration: The Austin Post aerial photo collection (dating from 1960-1995) contains over 100,000 images of North American valley glaciers. There is no other comprehensive photographic archive documenting the state of glaciers in western North America from 1960-1995 and the community no longer has access to these photos, because they exist largely in roll-film negative form at an archive center with no capability for scanning or printing them; this also poses a long-term archival risk. This proposal has one overarching goal; rescue the Austin Post aerial photo collection. This consists of high resolution photogrammetric scanning of approximately 30% of the roll-film, metadata generation, flight-line reconstruction, photo geolocation, and digital archival at both national archive centers and consumer photo sharing sites. The digital forms of these photos will be archived at several sites and there is also a great potential for a wide and spectacular dissemination and broader impact, simply by the planned distribution of selected pictures and what scientific message they may be conveying in an unusual visual clear and convincing way to the broad public, including decision-makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used a photogrammetric roll film scanner to digitize approximately 15,000 vertical air photos collected between 1970 – 1995 by the USGS to document the state of glaciers in western North America, primarily in Alaska.  We determined these scans are suitable for the measurement of surface elevations and thus measurements of volume change over time, during a period when no other such measurements are available. The scans were saved as raw tiffs, which were then  optimized for contrast and exposure as full resolution tiffs (~40 MB each), full resolution jpgs (~26MB), and large jpg thumbnails (~300 kB).  Nearly all photos were geolocated by comparison to Google Earth; these coordinates were compiled into the metadata for each frame, including all notes written into the film header such as altitude, glacier name, etc.  The thumbnails are arranged into Google Earth KML files by mission date, such that one can fly to an area of interest and see when photos are available.  Perhaps more importantly, by arranging the photos graphically in this way, a scientific user can see which photos have suitable overlaps for photogrammetric processing and what time-series may be available for study.  In addition to scientific uses, this collection represents the best and most systematic visual record of glacier volume loss in Alaska, and anyone seeking to understand the impacts of climate change on the landscape will find value in these photos.
